item.title: Tamara add a quote by Julio Cortazar
item.description: "Now I am an axolotl." -- Julio Cortazar

item.title: Tamara add a quote by Robert Penn Warren
item.description: "Storytelling and copulation are the two chief forms of amusement in the South. They’re inexpensive and easy to procure. " -- Robert Penn Warren

item.title: Tamara add a quote by Groucho Marx
item.description: "Outside of a dog, a book is man's best friend. Inside of a dog it's too dark to read." -- Groucho Marx

item.title: Tamara add a quote by E.E. Cummings
item.description: "since the thing perhaps is to eat flowers and not to be afraid" -- E.E. Cummings

item.title: Tamara add a quote by Antoine de Saint-Exupéry
item.description:
"Quand tu veux construire un bateau, ne commence pas par rassembler du bois, couper des planches et distribuer du travail, mais reveille au sein des hommes le desir de la mer grande et large.
If you want to build a ship, don't drum up people together to collect wood and don't assign them tasks and work, but rather teach them to long for the endless immensity of the sea." -- Antoine de Saint-Exupéry

item.title: Tamara add a quote by William Faulkner
item.description: "If a story is in you, it has to come out." -- William Faulkner

item.title: Tamara add a quote by Tayeb Salih
item.description: "Everyone who is educated today wants to sit at a comfortable desk under a fan and live in an air-conditioned house surrounded by a garden, coming and going in an American car as wide as the street. If we do not tear out this disease by the roots we shall have with us a bourgeoisie that is in no way connected with the reality of our life..." -- Tayeb Salih

item.title: Tamara add a quote by Antonio Machado
item.description: "I dreamt -- marvellous error! -- that I had a beehive here inside my heart. And the golden bees were making white combs and sweet honey from my old failures." -- Antonio Machado

item.title: Tamara add a quote by Walt Whitman
item.description: "This is what you shall do; Love the earth and sun and the animals, despise riches, give alms to every one that asks, stand up for the stupid and crazy, devote your income and labor to others, hate tyrants, argue not concerning God, have patience and indulgence toward the people, take off your hat to nothing known or unknown or to any man or number of men, go freely with powerful uneducated persons and with the young and with the mothers of families, read these leaves in the open air every season of every year of your life, re-examine all you have been told at school or church or in any book, dismiss whatever insults your own soul, and your very flesh shall be a great poem and have the richest fluency not only in its words but in the silent lines of its lips and face and between the lashes of your eyes and in every motion and joint of your body." -- Walt Whitman

item.title: Tamara add a quote by Italo Calvino
item.description: "Arriving at each new city, the traveler finds again a past of his that he did not know he had: the foreignness of what you no longer are or no longer possess lies in wait for you in foreign, unpossessed places." -- Italo Calvino

item.title: Tamara add a quote by Julio Cortázar
item.description: "Once in a while it happens that I vomit up a bunny... it's not reason for one to blush and isolate oneself and to walk around keeping one's mouth shut." -- Julio Cortázar

item.title: Tamara add a quote by Dee Dee Ramone
item.description: "We didn't have a positive song until we wrote 'Now I Wanna Sniff Some Glue!" -- Dee Dee Ramone

item.title: Tamara add a quote by Louis-Ferdinand Celine
item.description: "To hell with reality! I want to die in music, not in reason or in prose. People don't deserve the restraint we show by not going into delirium in front of them. To hell with them!" -- Louis-Ferdinand Celine

item.title: Tamara add a quote by Tove Jansson
item.description: "I ONLY WANT TO LIVE IN PEACE AND PLANT POTATOES AND DREAM!" -- Tove Jansson

item.title: Tamara add a quote by Georges Simenon
item.description: "The place smelled of fairgrounds, of lazy crowds, of nights when you stayed out because you couldn't go to bed, and it smelled like New York, of its calm and brutal indifference." -- Georges Simenon
